If you had been sitting at a sidewalk: oaf© along the Corso Vannucoi in the hill-set
Italian oity of Perugia on the bright autumn afternoon of September 26, you soon would have
discovered somethings
The fifth annual invasion of Perugia by American Fulbright scholars had taken plaoe.
It wasn’t that the Americans were dressed improperly or that they behaved badly. Almost
without exception, they were dressed as they might be for a Sunday afternoon stroll in early
autumn in their home towns in America. And they behaved well*
But dress and behavior nevertheless distinguished them from the thousands of Perugin-
ians, who had come out to the Corso to take the air and greet their friends, while strolling
the half-kilometer length of the city’s main street.
Somehow the Americans seemed more casual — in both dress and manner — than even the
most casual Italians on the Corso* For the men Fulbrightera the give-away characteristics
could be the cuts of both their hair and their sport jackets} the hang of their grey
flannels; or their loafer-style shoes. For the girls, too, the low-heeled loafers, the
hair-does, and the generally more casual sweaters and skirts were distinguishing.
In addition, many of the Americans started out immediately to soak up in a hurry what¬
ever Perugia had to offer of historical or cultural value.
With guide books or without, they studied the great Pisano fountain, or gas:ed at the
lovely Gothic communal palace, or wandered into the Cathedral of Ian Lorenzo, where they
claim to have the wedding ring of the virgin Mary.
Perhaps you remember, from the previous letter from It sly, the summary of these activi¬
ties of the newly-arrived Folbrigliters by the young oomposer, Marshall Bialoaky, from
Cleveland, Ohio, and the faculty of Milton college, Wisconsin?

HOVETi So it was obvious that Sunday afternoon that the 2954 American Fulbright group
had arrived in Perugia for its month of orientation, prior to scattering across the Italian
peninsula for an academia year of work.
The Feruginians now take this annual invasion in stride, and no doubt you could have
heard many of them along the Corso, saying to on© another-1 "The Americans have come again.”
And many would be smiling when they said it. •
That American group this year numbered more than a hundred. Half a dozen were pro¬
fessors who would be visiting lecturers at Italian universities. Nine more were persons of
professorial rank who had come to Italy to do research in their respective branches of
learning.
